Name: Name Recognition (Respond to Name)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 4, Level 2 by Week 6, Level 3 by Week 8
Short Description: This skill teaches your dog to turn toward you when you say their name.
Long Description: Name recognition helps your dog understand that hearing their name means they should look at you immediately. It strengthens communication, increases engagement, and serves as the foundation for all future obedience cues.
Brief Instructions Step 1: Say your dog’s name once and reward when they look.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin in a quiet space with minimal distractions. Say your dog’s name once, and the moment they turn toward you, mark the behaviour with a cheerful 'Yes!' and reward them.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Repeat this several times in short sessions so the dog begins forming a habit of checking in.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Once your dog responds consistently, begin practicing in new environments such as different rooms, the hallway, backyard, and eventually outdoors.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Increase difficulty by introducing mild distractions, but always set the dog up to succeed.
General Tips: Always say your dog’s name in a friendly tone. Avoid using their name for scolding or corrections, because this can make them hesitate. Keep your training sessions short so your dog stays engaged and eager to learn.
Troubleshooting: If your dog ignores their name, reduce distractions and use a higher-value reward. If they respond too slowly, try using a more cheerful tone and reward faster responses more generously. If they respond indoors but not outside, go back a step and practice in a quieter outdoor area.
Progressions: Look, Recall, Heel, Leave It, Stay
Preparation Tips: Prepare a handful of soft, high-value treats and begin in the quietest environment available.
Training Insights: Dogs often do not generalize learning to new environments easily. This skill becomes reliable only after you intentionally practice it in multiple situations.
Achievement Level 2: Responds in moderately distracting environments like backyard or driveway.
Achievement Level 3: Responds instantly in busy or stimulating environments.
Pass Criteria: Dog turns toward you within one second in quiet settings.
Fail Criteria: Dog ignores name three times in a row.
Mastery Criteria: Dog responds immediately in any environment regardless of distractions.

Name: Sit
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Sit teaches your dog to place their bottom on the ground on cue.
Long Description: Sit is one of the most important foundational behaviours for building calmness and impulse control. It helps teach your dog how to pause, listen, and remain still, which supports polite greetings, leash manners, stays, and doorway control.
Brief Instructions Step 1: Lure your dog upward into a sit.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin in a low-distraction environment. Hold a treat to your dog’s nose and slowly lift your hand upward so their bottom naturally moves into a sitting position. Mark and reward immediately once the dog sits.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Once they follow the hand movement consistently, say 'Sit' right before you lure them.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Begin fading the lure by using the same hand motion without a treat in your hand, rewarding from your other hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Build duration by asking your dog to sit and holding the position for one or two seconds before marking and rewarding. Gradually increase duration as your dog becomes more consistent.
Detailed Instructions Step 5: Practice in new environments, and eventually add distractions like movement or sounds.
General Tips: Avoid repeating the cue, as this teaches your dog that the first cue is optional. Reward calm, still sitting rather than excited bouncing. Keep the training sessions brief and fun to maintain motivation.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps popping up, decrease the duration and reward more quickly. If your dog does not sit in stimulating environments, return to an easier setting and increase reward value. If your dog lies down instead of sitting, raise your lure a little higher to encourage the correct movement.
Progressions: Stay, Down, Heel, Sit-Stay, Greeting Manners
Preparation Tips: Prepare tiny soft treats, a quiet room to begin training, and a treat pouch for easy access.
Training Insights: Sit becomes a dog’s default behaviour when they are unsure what to do, which helps reduce unwanted behaviours such as jumping or pulling.
Achievement Level 2: Sits on different surfaces and holds position for 5–10 seconds.
Achievement Level 3: Sits immediately in busy environments and holds for 15 seconds or more.
Fail Criteria: Dog requires multiple cues or breaks position.
Mastery Criteria: Dog sits instantly in any environment and maintains position until released.

Name: Zen Sit (Impulse-Control Sit)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: This teaches your dog to sit calmly while resisting temptation, such as food or toys.
Long Description: Zen Sit strengthens impulse control by teaching the dog that remaining calm and sitting patiently leads to access to rewards. This skill is useful for greeting manners, doorway control, feeding routines, and helping excitable dogs regulate their emotions.
Brief Instructions Step 3: Reward when the dog stays still.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by asking your dog to sit. Hold a treat in a closed hand near their face. If they stay seated and avoid lunging or pawing, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Slowly increase difficulty by opening your hand slightly or lowering the treat toward the floor. Reward only when your dog maintains the sit.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add movement such as stepping backward or sideways to test stability. Gradually introduce more tempting items like toys or food bowls.
General Tips: Be patient and reward calm behaviour. Work in very small increments and avoid making the challenge too difficult too quickly.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps breaking the sit, reduce the difficulty and reward more frequently. If they become overly frustrated, reset with an easy win. If they stare obsessively at the treat, hold it closer to your chest to reduce fixation.
Progressions: Stay, Leave It, Greeting Manners, Heel
Preparation Tips: Start with medium-value treats, a quiet area, and have your dog warmed up with a few basic sits.
Training Insights: Zen Sit forms the basis for all impulse-control exercises and greatly improves self-regulation in excitable dogs.
Achievement Level 1: Can hold sit with treat in closed hand.
Achievement Level 2: Can resist open-hand treat or mild movement.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains sit around high-value distractions or toys.
Mastery Criteria: Dog ignores temptations in all environments and maintains sit until released.

Name: Down (Lie Down)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lie down on cue.
Long Description: Down helps your dog relax and encourages calmness. It is extremely helpful during overstimulating situations, restaurant outings, vet visits, grooming sessions, and stay training. A reliable down increases safety and control.
Brief Instructions Step 1: Lure dog from sit to floor.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin in a quiet environment. Start your dog in a sit. Hold a treat at their nose and slowly move your hand straight down between their paws. As their elbows touch the floor, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Once they follow the lure consistently, add the cue 'Down' before moving your hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Begin fading the lure by using an empty hand signal and rewarding afterward.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Build duration gradually by asking your dog to hold the down for a few seconds before rewarding.
General Tips: Use small movements when luring and reward quickly when the dog gets into position. Keep the training relaxed, as this cue is tied to calm behaviour.
Troubleshooting: If your dog pops up immediately, lower your reward timing. If they crawl forward instead of lying down, lure closer to their chest. If they refuse to lie down, try training on a softer surface.
Progressions: Down-Stay, Settle, Place, Calm Public Behaviour
Preparation Tips: Use a soft mat or carpet at first, and prepare small treats.
Training Insights: Down teaches emotional regulation and is an essential foundation for calmness training.
Achievement Level 2: Downs in new rooms or yard.
Achievement Level 3: Downs in public with significant distractions.
Pass Criteria: Dog lies down on first cue.
Fail Criteria: Dog resists or pops back up.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs down anywhere and stays down until released.

Name: Zen Down (Impulse-Control Down)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lie down and resist distractions such as food, toys, or movement.
Long Description: Zen Down builds on the Down cue by teaching your dog to remain relaxed even when tempting or distracting stimuli are present. It supports long-duration stays, calm field trips, and polite behaviour at home.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Ask your dog to lie down. Hold a treat in your hand and slowly move it around—if the dog stays down, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Increase difficulty by placing the treat on the floor and covering it with your hand. Reward only when the dog remains still.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Introduce movement, such as stepping backward or to the side, while expecting the dog to hold their down.
General Tips: Stay patient and increase difficulty gradually. Keep sessions short to prevent frustration. Reward calm breathing and relaxed posture.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps breaking the down, reduce the distraction level. If they become overly excited, use lower-value treats. If they whine or scoot forward, practice easier reps.
Progressions: Down-Stay, Settle on Mat, Public Calmness
Preparation Tips: Use a non-slippery surface and medium-value treats. Start in a low-distraction room.
Training Insights: Zen Down greatly strengthens patience and emotional control, making it ideal for dogs who struggle to settle.
Achievement Level 1: Holds down against mild treat distraction.
Achievement Level 3: Holds down around toys, food bowls, or outdoor activity.
Mastery Criteria: Dog stays down calmly even during high-level distractions.

Name: Wait
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: This teaches the dog to pause and remain still until released.
Long Description: Wait improves safety and self-control. It teaches your dog to pause before exiting doors, crossing roads, jumping from the car, or approaching food. Unlike 'Stay,' Wait is typically a short pause instead of a long-duration hold.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by asking your dog to sit. Hold your hand out like a stop sign and say 'Wait.'
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take one small step backward. If the dog remains still, return and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually increase distance or duration, but keep early reps very short.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Use Wait during daily routines such as opening doors or feeding time.
General Tips: Keep your movements small at first. Always return to your dog to reward rather than calling them toward you, which prevents confusion with recall.
Troubleshooting: If your dog rushes forward, reduce distance and duration. If they become overly excited, wait for calmness before rewarding. If they creep forward, reset position and try again more slowly.
Preparation Tips: Have treats ready and practice near a door or food bowl.
Training Insights: Wait is one of the most useful real-world cues and builds excellent manners.
Achievement Level 3: Reliable at doors, cars, and in outdoor environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog waits consistently in all real-life situations until released.

Name: Stay
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to remain in a fixed position until released.
Long Description: Stay teaches your dog self-control, focus, and patience. It prevents rushing out of doors, jumping on people, wandering away, or breaking positions during training. A reliable Stay improves safety and teaches emotional regulation.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by asking your dog to sit or lie down. Hold your hand out with a flat palm and say 'Stay' in a calm voice.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take one small step backward. If your dog remains still, return to them and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually add distance, duration, and distractions one at a time.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Always return to your dog to reward them before releasing them. This builds strong position holding.
General Tips: Work slowly and increase difficulty gradually. Always return to your dog before releasing to avoid creating a habit of breaking position.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps breaking the stay, reduce distance or duration. If they get confused, reset with an easy success. If they become restless, shorten sessions.
Preparation Tips: Choose a quiet area, prepare treats, and mark out clear distance goals.
Training Insights: Stay is one of the most valuable safety cues and requires patience and consistent practice.
Achievement Level 1: Holds position for 3–5 seconds with minimal distraction.
Achievement Level 2: Holds for 10–20 seconds with mild distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Holds for 30+ seconds in real-world environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds position in any environment until released.

Name: Wrong (Non-Reward Marker)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog that their choice did not earn a reward but is not a punishment.
Long Description: A non-reward marker helps clarify communication. It gently tells the dog that the behaviour they offered is not the correct one, without using fear or intimidation. This reduces frustration and speeds up learning.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by asking for an easy behaviour such as Sit. If the dog does something different, calmly say 'Wrong' in a neutral tone.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Remove the treat from view and pause for a moment.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reset and ask again. Reward them when they offer the correct behaviour.
General Tips: Use a neutral tone—never frustrated. Keep the dog’s confidence high by rewarding the correct attempt immediately.
Troubleshooting: If the dog seems discouraged, reduce difficulty. If they become confused, simplify the task. If they ignore the marker, practice with easier exercises.
Progressions: Precision Commands, Shaping Work, Advanced Obedience
Preparation Tips: Have treats ready and choose an easy starting behaviour.
Training Insights: A non-reward marker bridges the communication gap and prevents dogs from feeling punished during mistakes.
Achievement Level 1: Dog pauses when they hear the marker.
Achievement Level 3: Dog adjusts behaviour without frustration.
Mastery Criteria: Dog uses marker feedback constructively.

Name: No (Corrective Cue Used Responsibly)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to stop an unsafe or unwanted behaviour, used with care and clear structure.
Long Description: ‘No’ is a cue that should only be introduced after positive training foundations are established. When used correctly, it communicates that a behaviour must stop immediately for safety or household rules. It should never be paired with yelling or intimidation.
Brief Instructions Step 3: Redirect and reward the correct behaviour.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin in a calm environment. When your dog engages in a mild unwanted behaviour such as pawing for treats, say 'No' once in a firm but neutral voice.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Pause for one second, then guide your dog toward the correct behaviour, such as sitting.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Mark and reward the correct choice. This teaches your dog that ‘No’ means stop and choose a better option.
General Tips: Use this cue sparingly. Always follow ‘No’ with guidance toward the correct behaviour. Never shout or use it emotionally.
Troubleshooting: If your dog becomes scared, your tone is too harsh. If they ignore it, the behaviour is too rewarding or environment too stimulating. If they shut down, pause training and rebuild confidence.
Progressions: Leave It, Off, Boundary Training, Safety Commands
Preparation Tips: Choose simple situations to introduce the cue and avoid using it in high-emotion moments.
Training Insights: ‘No’ works best as part of a calm, consistent communication system—not a punishment.
Achievement Level 3: Responds instantly to prevent unsafe behaviours.
Mastery Criteria: Dog stops and offers an alternative behaviour independently.

Name: Leave It
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to move away from something and ignore it on cue.
Long Description: Leave It is one of the most important safety cues. It prevents dogs from picking up dangerous objects, chasing animals, grabbing food, or fixating on distractions. This skill teaches strong impulse control and builds trust.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a treat in your closed fist and present it to your dog. When they stop sniffing or pawing and look away, mark and reward with a different treat from your other hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Progress to showing a treat in an open hand and rewarding when your dog chooses to ignore it.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Practice leaving items on the floor, toys, and eventually real-life distractions such as food or wildlife.
General Tips: Always reward your dog for choosing to disengage. Work slowly so your dog builds trust in the cue. Start with low-value items and move up.
Troubleshooting: If your dog grabs the item, lower difficulty. If they become frustrated, shorten sessions. If they stare intensely, lift the item higher.
Preparation Tips: Use low-value treats at first and have higher-value rewards available in your other hand.
Training Insights: Leave It builds self-control and prevents countless dangerous situations.
Achievement Level 1: Ignores low-value treat in closed hand.
Achievement Level 2: Ignores open-hand treat or item on floor.
Achievement Level 3: Leaves tempting real-world distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog leaves anything on cue in any environment.

Name: Off
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to remove their paws or body from furniture, people, or objects.
Long Description: Off teaches polite manners by helping your dog understand when physical contact—such as jumping on people, climbing on counters, or getting on furniture—is not appropriate. This cue promotes safety, prevents injury, and encourages calm respectful interactions.
Brief Instructions Step 3: Reward when all paws are down.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: When your dog jumps up on a person, counter, or furniture, say 'Off' once in a neutral, calm voice.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Guide them toward the floor using a hand signal, or step slightly into their space so they naturally move down.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: The moment all four paws return to the ground, mark and reward. This teaches the dog that keeping paws down earns rewards.
General Tips: Stay calm and consistent. Reward immediately when the dog chooses to stay on the floor. Avoid pushing the dog off, as it can create excitement.
Troubleshooting: If your dog jumps more when excited, practice in low-energy situations first. If they ignore the cue, reward calm four-paws-on-floor more often. If they jump for attention, turn away briefly and reward when they settle.
Progressions: Greeting Manners, Heel, Calm Household Behaviour
Preparation Tips: Prepare treats and begin in a location where jumping commonly occurs.
Training Insights: Dogs jump because it works. Teaching 'Off' paired with rewarding calmness prevents future jumping.
Achievement Level 2: Responds with guests or mild distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Responds reliably in exciting greeting situations.
Pass Criteria: Dog gets down on first cue.
Mastery Criteria: Dog automatically keeps paws down without being told.

Name: On Your Mat / Bed
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to go to a designated spot and relax.
Long Description: This skill gives your dog a predictable place to settle, which is extremely helpful during mealtimes, guest arrivals, busy households, or café/restaurant visits. Place training reduces anxiety by giving the dog a clear job.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by placing a mat or bed in a quiet area. Lure your dog onto the mat using a treat. When all four paws are on the mat, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: After several repetitions, add the cue 'Mat' or 'Bed' just before luring.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually build duration by rewarding your dog for staying on the mat for longer periods.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Add distance by sending your dog to the mat from farther away, and add distractions over time.
General Tips: Reward your dog frequently during early sessions. Make the mat a positive, cozy place. Use it during natural downtime like meals or relaxation periods.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps stepping off the mat, reduce duration expectations. If they refuse to go to the mat, use higher-value treats. If they get too excited, pause training until calmer.
Preparation Tips: Use a mat with good traction and have small treats ready.
Training Insights: Place training helps manage household behaviour and builds strong self-settling skills.
Achievement Level 1: Goes to mat on cue indoors.
Achievement Level 3: Uses mat reliably in public environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog settles on mat automatically in busy settings.

Name: Heel
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 22
Short Description: Teaches the dog to walk close to your side with focus and control.
Long Description: Heel requires your dog to move beside you in a controlled and attentive manner. Unlike loose-leash walking, Heel is a precise position used for focused training, crowded environments, and high-control scenarios such as crossing roads or passing distractions.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by standing with your dog beside your left leg. Lure them into position with a treat.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take one or two steps forward while keeping the treat at your left side. Mark and reward when the dog stays in position.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Increase distance gradually, adding turns and changes of speed.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Fade the lure by rewarding less frequently and relying on verbal cues.
General Tips: Reward frequently while the dog is learning. Keep sessions short to avoid frustration. Practice indoors before adding distractions.
Troubleshooting: If your dog pulls ahead, stop and reset. If they lag behind, increase excitement. If they drift outward, reward closer to your leg.
Progressions: Advanced Leash Walking, Focused Heelwork, Recall
Preparation Tips: Use a well-fitted harness or collar, treats, and a quiet hallway or driveway.
Training Insights: Heel builds exceptional focus and control, which benefits all other leash skills.
Achievement Level 3: Heels reliably near dogs, people, or heavy distractions.
Pass Criteria: Dog stays by your side briefly.
Fail Criteria: Dog pulls or drifts out of position.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains heel position in all environments.

Name: Come (Recall)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to return to you immediately when called.
Long Description: A strong recall is the most important safety behaviour in dog training. It prevents accidents, keeps your dog close around distractions, and allows safe off-leash freedom in appropriate environments. Dogs with reliable recall experience more freedom and make safer choices.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start indoors at a short distance. Call your dog by name followed by 'Come' in a happy voice. When they turn toward you and run to you, mark and reward generously.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Practice short distances until reliable, then increase the space, practicing in hallways, yards, and safe fenced areas.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add distractions gradually and use very high-value rewards for outdoor recalls.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Occasionally give a jackpot reward to maintain enthusiasm.
General Tips: Use an enthusiastic tone and reward generously every time, especially early in training. Never call your dog to punish or end something fun.
Troubleshooting: If your dog ignores the cue, reduce distractions and use better rewards. If they stop halfway, encourage with movement. If they avoid coming, rebuild positive associations.
Preparation Tips: Use a long-line leash, high-value treats, and practice in secure areas.
Training Insights: Recall should always feel rewarding and exciting for your dog.
Achievement Level 2: Comes in yard or quiet outdoor spaces.
Achievement Level 3: Comes in busy or high-distraction environments.
Pass Criteria: Dog turns and runs to you.
Mastery Criteria: Dog recalls instantly even during distractions like dogs, smells, or play.

Name: Nicely (Polite Loose-Leash Walking Cue)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to walk politely without pulling.
Long Description: The 'Nicely' cue helps your dog understand that pulling on the leash is not allowed and that staying near you with light leash tension is rewarding. This cue improves comfort, safety, and communication during everyday walks.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin walking in a quiet area. When the leash is loose, say 'Nicely' in a calm tone and reward your dog for staying close.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: If your dog begins to pull, stop walking immediately. Wait for the leash to loosen or for your dog to check in, then mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Practice stopping and starting consistently so your dog learns that pulling ends the walk but polite walking keeps it going.
General Tips: Reward often during early stages. Keep sessions short to avoid frustration. Use gentle movements and avoid jerking the leash.
Troubleshooting: If your dog pulls constantly, move to a quieter area. If they become frustrated, use higher-value treats. If they lag behind, encourage with a happy voice.
Preparation Tips: Use a well-fitted harness and treats, and choose a quiet area to begin.
Training Insights: Loose-leash walking develops better communication and makes outdoor experiences enjoyable rather than stressful.
Achievement Level 1: Walks politely indoors or on driveway.
Achievement Level 2: Maintains loose leash in yard or quiet streets.
Achievement Level 3: Walks nicely in high-distraction areas.
Mastery Criteria: Dog walks politely in all environments with minimal cues.

Name: Look (Watch Me / Focus)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog to make eye contact on cue.
Long Description: The Look cue improves your dog’s focus and engagement. It helps redirect attention away from distractions and strengthens communication, making all other training easier and more effective.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin in a quiet environment. Hold a treat near your face and say 'Look.' When your dog makes eye contact, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually remove the lure by using an empty hand signal.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Practice in new rooms, then the yard, and eventually outdoors. Increase difficulty by adding mild distractions.
General Tips: Reward immediately at first to build clear understanding. Keep training sessions short and fun. Use a cheerful tone.
Troubleshooting: If your dog avoids eye contact, hold the treat closer to your face. If they look away frequently, reduce distractions. If they stare at the treat instead of your eyes, hide the treat behind your back and reward afterward.
Preparation Tips: Use soft treats and begin in a calm indoor space.
Training Insights: Eye contact builds strong communication and is essential for managing distractions in real-life environments.
Achievement Level 2: Maintains eye contact around mild distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains eye contact in busy environments.
Pass Criteria: Dog looks at you on cue.
Mastery Criteria: Dog offers automatic check-ins even without cue.

Name: Release Command (Okay)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog that a behaviour or position is finished and they are free to move.
Long Description: The Release cue is essential for clear communication. It tells your dog when a command such as Sit, Down, Stay, or Mat is complete, preventing confusion and teaching your dog to hold positions until they hear the release word.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by asking your dog to sit or lie down. Hold the position for one or two seconds.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Say your release cue—such as 'Okay!'—in an upbeat tone, then encourage your dog to move.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reward them after they move to reinforce that the release word means the exercise is finished.
General Tips: Use the release word consistently and only when you truly intend to end the behaviour. Avoid using it casually in conversation.
Troubleshooting: If your dog breaks positions early, reduce duration. If they seem confused, practice very short holds before releasing. If they ignore the release, increase your enthusiasm.
Progressions: Extended Stays, Mat Work, Duration Behaviours
Preparation Tips: Choose a clear, simple release word and prepare small treats.
Training Insights: The Release cue creates structure and prevents your dog from guessing when an exercise is finished.
Achievement Level 2: Holds position until release with mild distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Holds position in public until released.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds commands until release in all environments.

Name: Stand
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to rise into a standing position and remain still.
Long Description: Stand is extremely useful for grooming, vet visits, wiping paws, and body handling. It also improves body awareness and supports advanced obedience positions used in sports or precision heelwork.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start with your dog in a sit or down. Hold a treat in front of their nose and slowly move it forward. As they rise into a stand, mark and reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Once they perform the behaviour reliably, add the verbal cue 'Stand' before luring.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Build duration by rewarding your dog for staying in the stand position for a few seconds, then gradually increasing the duration.
General Tips: Reward calm stillness. Avoid luring too quickly or too high. Keep the dog’s posture straight by rewarding close to their chest.
Troubleshooting: If your dog steps forward instead of standing in place, lure more slowly. If they keep sitting again, give shorter duration requests. If they seem confused, practice from a down position instead.
Progressions: Grooming Handling, Veterinary Cooperative Care, Precision Obedience
Preparation Tips: Use treats and practice on a non-slip surface.
Training Insights: Stand builds confidence and teaches your dog to remain stable during handling.
Achievement Level 3: Holds stand during grooming or vet handling.
Pass Criteria: Dog transitions into stand on cue.
Fail Criteria: Dog sits or lies down instead.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds stand confidently during real handling.

Name: Place (Go to Place)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to go to a defined spot and remain there until released.
Long Description: Place training provides your dog with a clear job and a designated relaxation location. It helps reduce overexcitement, supports polite behaviour during meals or guest arrivals, and provides structure for dogs who struggle to settle.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by showing your dog the place item (mat, bed, platform). Lure them onto it and mark the moment all four paws touch the surface. Reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Repeat until consistent, then add the cue 'Place' right before luring.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Begin adding duration by rewarding your dog for remaining on the place for increasing amounts of time.
Detailed Instructions Step 4: Gradually add distractions, distance, and real-life applications (mealtime, door knocking).
General Tips: Reward frequently at first to build a strong positive association. Use Place during natural downtime such as meals or relaxing.
Troubleshooting: If your dog steps off the place, calmly reset them. If they hesitate to go on, use higher-value treats. If they break frequently, reduce distractions.
Preparation Tips: Choose a clearly defined Place surface and have treats ready.
Training Insights: Place training is one of the strongest calmness-building tools for dogs with high energy or anxiety.
Achievement Level 3: Uses place reliably in public settings.
Mastery Criteria: Dog remains calmly on place in busy real-life scenarios.

Name: Drop It
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to release an item from their mouth.
Long Description: Drop It is essential for safety and prevents guarding or dangerous object ingestion. Teaching your dog to willingly release objects builds trust, reduces conflict, and allows for safe play with toys.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with a toy your dog enjoys but is not overly obsessed with. Offer a treat near their nose; when they drop the toy to take the treat, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add the cue 'Drop It' right before presenting the treat.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Practice with different toys, increasing difficulty gradually. Never chase your dog for items, as this builds possessiveness.
General Tips: Always trade politely. Avoid pulling items from your dog’s mouth. Use calm, consistent cues and reward generously.
Troubleshooting: If your dog runs away with items, use lower-value toys. If they refuse to drop, increase reward value. If they guard objects, practice with safe, non-valued items first.
Progressions: Retrieve Games, Impulse Control, Leave It
Preparation Tips: Use two toys or high-value treats for trading.
Training Insights: Drop It strengthens trust and prevents unwanted or dangerous object swallowing.
Achievement Level 3: Drops high-value items or food distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog drops anything on cue, even under excitement.

Name: Fetch
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to retrieve an item and bring it back.
Long Description: Fetch builds physical exercise, mental stimulation, and teamwork between you and your dog. It can help strengthen recall, reduce boredom, and provide structured play for high-energy dogs.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by tossing a toy a short distance. Encourage your dog to chase it.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they return with the toy, reward them immediately, even if they do not deliver it perfectly. This builds motivation to return.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add structure by asking for Drop It before throwing again. Keep sessions short to maintain excitement.
General Tips: Use toys your dog loves. Keep throws short at first. Always reward the return to reinforce the fetch cycle.
Troubleshooting: If your dog runs away with the toy, use two-toy games. If they won’t chase, increase excitement. If they drop the toy too early, reward closer and build distance gradually.
Progressions: Retrieve Sports, Agility Motivation, Recall Reinforcement
Preparation Tips: Choose a safe toy and open space with minimal distractions.
Training Insights: Fetch should always feel exciting and rewarding to keep motivation high.
Achievement Level 3: Retrieves reliably in distracting environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs reliable fetch with structured Drop It.

Name: Take It
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Teaches the dog to take an object gently on cue.
Long Description: Take It teaches your dog to wait for permission before taking food or toys. This improves impulse control, prevents grabbing, and teaches polite manners around hands and objects.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a toy or treat in your hand while keeping your fist closed. When your dog waits calmly, say 'Take It' and open your hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Reward gentle taking by marking and praising.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually introduce more exciting items while reinforcing calmness.
General Tips: Never allow grabbing or lunging. Reward calm waiting before giving the cue.
Troubleshooting: If your dog grabs too hard, use less exciting items. If they grab early, close your hand quickly. If they seem confused, slow down and reward small steps.
Preparation Tips: Choose a low-excitement item at first and use calm handling.
Training Insights: Take It teaches impulse control and sets the foundation for polite use of toys or treats.
Achievement Level 3: Takes objects gently in exciting play situations.
Mastery Criteria: Dog takes any object gently on cue.

Name: Roll Over
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Teaches the dog to roll onto their back and complete a full rotation.
Long Description: Roll Over is a fun trick that improves flexibility, confidence, and comfort with body handling. It helps dogs become at ease with unusual positions and strengthens overall body awareness.
Brief Instructions Step 1: Lure your dog into a down.
Brief Instructions Step 2: Lure their head toward their shoulder.
Brief Instructions Step 3: Guide them through a full roll.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Ask your dog to lie down on a soft surface. Hold a treat by their nose and slowly lure their head toward their shoulder so they begin to roll onto their side.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Continue moving the treat in a circular motion so your dog rolls onto their back and then completes the rotation onto their other side.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Mark and reward as soon as they finish the roll. Practice in short, positive sessions, rewarding even partial rolls at first.
General Tips: Train on a soft, non-slip surface so your dog feels comfortable. Move the lure slowly and clearly so they can follow it. Reward attempts generously at the beginning.
Troubleshooting: If your dog pops up instead of rolling, slow your hand movement and keep it close to their nose. If they resist rolling fully, reward for smaller movements like shifting onto their side and gradually build up. If they seem uncomfortable, try a softer surface or end the session and try again later.
Progressions: Advanced Tricks, Body Awareness Games, Cooperative Handling
Preparation Tips: Use a soft mat or carpeted area and prepare high-value treats. Make sure your dog is relaxed and not overly excited before starting.
Training Insights: Roll Over helps dogs become more comfortable with touch and handling, which can make grooming and vet care less stressful over time.
Achievement Level 1: Performs a full roll with a clear lure indoors.
Achievement Level 2: Performs a roll with minimal luring and light distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Performs a roll on verbal cue alone in a variety of environments.
Pass Criteria: Dog completes a full roll with your guidance.
Fail Criteria: Dog repeatedly pops up or refuses to roll.
Mastery Criteria: Dog rolls smoothly on a single cue without needing a hand lure, even in new places.

Name: Touch (Hand Target)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog to touch your hand with their nose.
Long Description: Touch is a simple but powerful focus exercise that encourages your dog to interact with you. It can be used to redirect attention, build confidence, move your dog into position, and form the basis for many more complex tricks.
Brief Instructions Step 2: Mark when your dog touches it.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: In a quiet room, hold your open hand a few centimetres from your dog’s nose. The moment they reach forward and touch your hand with their nose, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Repeat this several times until your dog is consistently touching your hand. Then begin saying 'Touch' just before presenting your hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Once your dog understands, start varying the position of your hand (slightly higher, lower, or to the side) to help them generalize the behaviour.
General Tips: Keep your hand close at first to make success easy. Use a happy voice and reward every touch during the early stages. Keep sessions short so your dog stays engaged.
Troubleshooting: If your dog seems unsure and does not approach your hand, move it closer to their nose and wait patiently. If they lick or mouth your hand instead of touching gently, flatten your hand and reward only light touches. If they lose focus easily, reduce distractions and use higher-value treats.
Progressions: Heel Engagement, Spin, Redirecting Arousal, Target-Based Tricks
Preparation Tips: Have small soft treats ready and choose a calm indoor space so your dog can concentrate.
Training Insights: Touch is an excellent way to build engagement with shy or easily distracted dogs because it gives them a clear, simple job to succeed at.
Achievement Level 1: Touches your hand reliably indoors with minimal distraction.
Achievement Level 2: Can perform Touch in different rooms or the yard with some distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Responds to the Touch cue in busy environments like parks or training classes.
Pass Criteria: Dog touches your hand promptly when cued.
Fail Criteria: Dog avoids your hand or seems confused after several attempts.
Mastery Criteria: Dog can target your hand confidently in any environment and in a variety of positions.

Name: High Five
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to raise a paw and tap your open hand.
Long Description: High Five is a fun party trick that builds your dog’s confidence and comfort with having their paws handled. It can also be a stepping stone to other paw-based behaviours such as Wave or Shake.
Brief Instructions Step 3: Reward when their paw touches your hand.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start with your dog in a sit. Hold your open palm a few centimetres in front of their chest. Many dogs will naturally lift a paw to investigate; as soon as their paw touches your hand, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: If they do not offer a paw, you can first encourage pawing by holding a treat in your closed fist and rewarding for paw contact, then switch to the open palm once they understand.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When your dog is reliably touching your palm, add the cue 'High Five' just before you present your hand.
General Tips: Reward small efforts early on, such as tiny paw lifts. Keep your hand steady and at a comfortable height. Train on a non-slip surface so your dog feels secure.
Troubleshooting: If your dog tries to use their mouth instead of their paw, raise your hand slightly higher and only reward paw contact. If they swipe too hard, calmly withdraw your hand and reward calmer touches. If they seem confused, go back to rewarding simple paw lifts and build up again.
Progressions: Wave, Shake, Hug, Other Paw Tricks
Preparation Tips: Prepare small treats and work on a stable, non-slippery floor surface.
Training Insights: High Five encourages your dog to offer behaviours confidently and can make them more relaxed about having their paws handled during grooming or vet visits.
Achievement Level 1: Offers a paw to your palm indoors with minimal distraction.
Achievement Level 2: Performs a clear High Five with moderate distractions present.
Achievement Level 3: Can High Five on cue in new environments and around other people.
Pass Criteria: Dog taps your open palm with their paw when cued.
Fail Criteria: Dog avoids using their paw or becomes frustrated.
Mastery Criteria: Dog offers a calm, controlled High Five in a variety of situations and with different people.

Name: Nose (Boop)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog to gently tap a hand, finger, or small object with their nose.
Long Description: Nose Boop is a cute targeting trick that also helps build precision and confidence. It can later be used in more advanced tasks like object targeting, pushing buttons, or interactive games.
Brief Instructions Step 2: Mark when your dog boops it with their nose.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold your hand, a finger, or a small target object a few centimetres from your dog’s nose. When they move forward and make contact with their nose, mark and reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Repeat several times until your dog is reliably booping the target, then begin saying 'Boop' just before presenting it.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Once they understand, start to slowly vary the position of the target (slightly higher, lower, or to the side) to generalize the behaviour.
General Tips: Keep the target very close at first so the behaviour feels easy. Reward frequently to keep the dog motivated. Use calm, clear body language.
Troubleshooting: If your dog mouths or bites at the target, pause briefly and only reward gentle nose touches. If they ignore the target, use a larger, more obvious target such as your open hand before progressing to smaller objects. If they become distracted, reduce environmental stimulation.
Progressions: Object Targeting, Button Pushing, Send-Away Targeting
Preparation Tips: Choose a clear target (such as your hand or a small object) and prepare several small treats. Start in a quiet area.
Training Insights: Nose Boop is a great stepping stone into more complex targeting behaviours and gives nervous dogs a simple way to succeed.
Achievement Level 1: Boops a target that is held very close in a quiet room.
Achievement Level 2: Boops targets presented at different angles or positions with some distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Boops small targets on cue in new or busy environments.
Pass Criteria: Dog touches the target with their nose when cued.
Fail Criteria: Dog consistently avoids or mouths the target.
Mastery Criteria: Dog confidently boops a variety of targets on cue in many different environments.

Name: Bow
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lower their front end while keeping hind legs standing.
Long Description: Bow improves flexibility, builds body awareness, and encourages confident stretching. It is a visually appealing trick and helps dogs become more comfortable with controlled posture changes.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start with your dog standing. Hold a treat near their nose and slowly lure their head downward and slightly forward so their chest lowers while their hind end stays up.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward the instant they hold the bow shape, even briefly.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When your dog consistently performs the motion, add the cue 'Bow' just before you begin luring.
General Tips: Use slow, smooth luring. Reward even partial bows. Train on a soft surface.
Troubleshooting: If the dog collapses into a down, lure slightly forward instead of straight down. If stiff, keep sessions short. If they seem confused, shape small movements first.
Preparation Tips: Use a non-slip surface and medium-value treats.
Training Insights: Bow helps dogs learn precise body positioning and encourages healthy stretching habits.
Achievement Level 3: Performs bow with distractions in new environments.
Mastery Criteria: Smooth controlled bow on cue anywhere.

Name: Hug
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to wrap their paws around an object or your arm.
Long Description: Hug is a cute bonding trick that helps dogs build confidence and controlled use of their paws. It can be taught using a stuffed toy first, then transferred to your arm.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: With your dog sitting, hold a stuffed toy or pillow close to their chest and reward any attempt to lift a paw toward it.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually shape the behaviour until your dog wraps one or both paws around the object. Mark and reward every improvement.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Hug' once your dog reliably performs the wrap.
General Tips: Reward small steps. Avoid encouraging jumping. Keep sessions short.
Troubleshooting: If your dog jumps up instead of hugging, reset by asking for sit. If unsure, use a familiar object. If stuck, break the movement into tiny shaping steps.
Preparation Tips: Use a stuffed toy or pillow and high-value treats.
Training Insights: Hug encourages controlled, gentle body contact and builds emotional connection.
Achievement Level 3: Holds hug for several seconds in new settings.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs gentle, controlled hug on cue.

Name: Hide (Hide Face / Shy)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to cover their nose or face with their paw.
Long Description: Hide is an adorable trick that improves paw awareness and confidence. It’s usually taught using a small piece of tape or sticker to prompt a natural paw swipe toward the face.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Place a small safe piece of tape lightly on your dog’s nose so they naturally lift a paw to swipe it off. Mark and reward when their paw touches their face.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually shape the behaviour so they touch their nose without the tape. Reward small improvements.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Hide' once the behaviour is reliable.
General Tips: Use very light tape and limit use to a few repetitions. Reward instantly.
Troubleshooting: If the dog gets irritated, remove tape promptly and reduce difficulty. If they swipe too hard, reduce excitement. If confused, reward tiny paw lifts and build gradually.
Preparation Tips: Have soft treats and small pieces of safe tape ready.
Training Insights: Hide helps dogs learn fine motor control with their paws and is great for shaping complex behaviours.
Achievement Level 3: Performs hide anywhere reliably.
Mastery Criteria: Smooth, cue-only face cover in different environments.

Name: Kiss
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 6, Level 2 by Week 8, Level 3 by Week 10
Short Description: Teaches the dog to gently touch their nose or mouth to your cheek or an object.
Long Description: Kiss is a simple bonding behaviour that encourages gentle, controlled interactions. It’s also easy to teach and can help dogs build comfort around close handling.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Sit close to your dog and present your cheek or a designated target object (like a stuffed toy). Hold a treat behind the target so your dog leans forward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they gently nose-touch the target, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Kiss' once your dog performs the behaviour consistently, and gradually fade the lure.
General Tips: Reward only gentle touches. Keep the target still. Use a clean object if avoiding direct face contact.
Troubleshooting: If your dog licks too much, reward only for brief touches. If hesitant, use a familiar object first. If overly excited, take breaks and slow down the session.
Preparation Tips: Use a target object and small treats. Sit at your dog’s level.
Training Insights: Kiss helps build trust, gentle behaviour, and positive close contact.
Achievement Level 3: Performs kiss calmly around distractions.
Fail Criteria: Dog becomes overly excited or avoids.
Mastery Criteria: Dog offers gentle controlled 'kiss' on cue in any environment.

Name: Spin
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Teaches the dog to spin in a full circle on cue.
Long Description: Spin is a fun, dynamic trick that improves body awareness, rear-end coordination, and responsiveness. It is easy to teach and serves as an excellent warm-up exercise before more advanced training.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a treat near your dog’s nose and lure them in a wide circle. Move slowly so they follow comfortably.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they complete the circle, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: After several repetitions, add the cue 'Spin' just before beginning the lure. Gradually fade the lure until your dog performs the behaviour on verbal cue alone.
General Tips: Keep circles large at first to prevent confusion. Work on a non-slip surface. Reward generously.
Troubleshooting: If your dog stops halfway, lure more slowly. If they spin too wide, keep the treat closer. If confused, break the circle into halves.
Preparation Tips: Use small soft treats and practice in an open space.
Training Insights: Spin builds enthusiasm and confidence, making it ideal as an early trick for shy or low-motivation dogs.
Achievement Level 2: Spins on cue with some distractions.
Achievement Level 3: Spins reliably in new environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog spins smoothly on cue without hand signals anywhere.

Name: Bunny (Beg)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 16, Level 2 by Week 20, Level 3 by Week 24
Short Description: Teaches the dog to sit upright with front paws raised.
Long Description: Bunny (also called Beg) improves balance, core strength, and body control. It is adorable, physically challenging, and should be taught gradually to avoid strain.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with your dog in a sit. Hold a treat above their nose and slowly lure upward so they lift their front paws. Support lightly under their chest if needed.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Reward even brief moments of balance. Slowly build duration as their core strength improves.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Beg' or 'Bunny' once they can hold the position reliably.
General Tips: Train near a wall so your dog can steady themselves. Keep sessions short. Reward tiny progress.
Troubleshooting: If your dog keeps falling backward, lure lower. If they get frustrated, reduce expectations. If weak core strength, train in very small increments.
Progressions: Advanced Balance Tricks, Sit Pretty Holds
Preparation Tips: Practice on soft flooring and use medium or high-value treats.
Training Insights: This trick significantly builds core strength—avoid overtraining and let your dog rest between reps.
Achievement Level 2: Holds beg for 1–2 seconds on cue.
Achievement Level 3: Holds beg for several seconds with distractions.
Pass Criteria: Dog lifts paws into upright position.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds a controlled beg on cue in various environments.

Name: Wipe Paws
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Teaches the dog to wipe their paws on a mat before entering the house.
Long Description: Wipe Paws is a useful behaviour that helps keep floors clean and builds independence during grooming tasks. It uses a natural digging motion that most dogs easily shape.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Place a textured mat or towel on the ground. Encourage your dog to stand on it and reward any paw movement resembling a scratch.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When your dog begins pawing the mat, mark and reward multiple scratches in a row.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Wipe' or 'Paws' once your dog reliably performs the motion, and gradually move the mat toward doorways for real-life use.
General Tips: Choose a mat with grip. Reward multiple paw strokes. Keep sessions playful.
Troubleshooting: If your dog won’t scratch, hide a treat under the mat to encourage digging. If they over-excite, pause briefly. If they scratch the floor instead, reduce excitement and reposition the mat.
Preparation Tips: Use a textured doormat and soft treats. Begin indoors first.
Training Insights: Wipe Paws channels natural digging into a useful task, improving cleanliness and self-help behaviours.
Achievement Level 2: Wipes paws several times on cue.
Achievement Level 3: Performs full paw wipe sequence at doorways.
Fail Criteria: Dog avoids or scratches unrelated surfaces.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably wipes paws before entering the house.

Name: Tell a Secret
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Teaches the dog to place their nose or mouth near your ear as if whispering.
Long Description: Tell a Secret is an adorable interactive trick that reinforces gentle behaviour and controlled movement near your face. It photographs well and is a favourite for kids.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start by teaching your dog to target your hand near your cheek or ear with gentle nose touches.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually fade the hand and lure your dog closer to your ear. Mark and reward when they place their nose near your ear in a calm manner.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Secret' or 'Tell me a secret' once your dog performs the motion consistently. Keep rewards calm to maintain gentleness.
General Tips: Reward only soft, gentle touches. Keep the dog calm. Sit at their level for clarity.
Troubleshooting: If the dog licks excessively, reward only brief touches. If overly excited, slow the session and use lower-value treats. If hesitant, use a larger target hand fade gradually.
Preparation Tips: Sit at your dog’s level and use soft treats. Begin in a quiet space.
Training Insights: Tell a Secret teaches refined, gentle interaction and is excellent for dogs learning emotional control.
Achievement Level 3: Performs in distracting or public settings.
Pass Criteria: Dog gently places nose near ear.
Fail Criteria: Dog becomes overly excited or avoids.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs controlled, gentle 'secret' behaviour on cue anywhere.

Name: Snake (Weave Between Legs)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to weave through your legs in a flowing pattern.
Long Description: Snake is a stylish trick that builds confidence, rear-end awareness, and coordination. It helps dogs learn to move through tight spaces and stay connected to the handler.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand with legs apart. Lure your dog through your legs from front to back, marking and rewarding as soon as they pass fully through.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Repeat the movement from alternating sides, rewarding each successful weave.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Once your dog begins to anticipate the pattern, add the cue 'Snake' and gradually fade the lure, encouraging a smooth continuous flow.
General Tips: Keep your stance wide so the dog feels safe. Move slowly at first. Reward after each leg pass.
Troubleshooting: If your dog hesitates, widen your stance or lower the lure. If they go around instead of through, guide closer to your leg. If overwhelmed, take short breaks.
Progressions: Figure-8 Weaves, Dance Routines, Advanced Heelwork
Preparation Tips: Use treats and practice on a non-slip surface with plenty of space.
Training Insights: Snake builds fluid motion skills and strengthens connection during trick routines.
Achievement Level 3: Performs smooth flowing weaves without lure in public spaces.
Fail Criteria: Dog avoids leg space or stops midway.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs continuous weaves smoothly on cue.

Name: Jump on the Back
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 20, Level 2 by Week 26, Level 3 by Week 30
Short Description: Teaches the dog to gently hop onto your back from a controlled position.
Long Description: Jump on the Back is a dramatic stunt trick requiring strong trust, physical control, and handler stability. It must be taught slowly to ensure safety.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start by encouraging your dog to jump onto a low, stable platform behind you. Reward heavily for confident stepping or hopping.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually lower the platform and position yourself in a kneeling or crouched position so your back mimics the platform shape.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When your dog is comfortable stepping onto your back, add the cue such as 'Back' and slowly transition to a standing position over time.
General Tips: Use a soft surface. Keep your back stable. Move slowly and reward tiny steps.
Troubleshooting: If the dog hesitates, raise the platform height again. If they scramble or lose balance, lower difficulty. If nervous, keep sessions extremely short.
Preparation Tips: Use a training platform and choose a soft grass or mat surface.
Training Insights: This trick requires trust—go slowly and stop immediately if your dog seems unsure.
Achievement Level 2: Steps onto crouched back on cue.
Achievement Level 3: Jumps onto standing back confidently.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs stable controlled back stand on cue.

Name: Jump Into Arms
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 20, Level 2 by Week 26, Level 3 by Week 30
Short Description: Teaches the dog to jump safely into your arms on cue.
Long Description: Jump Into Arms is a high-trust, high-confidence trick requiring excellent coordination and controlled jumping. Teaching this trick properly prevents injury and builds a strong partnership.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin seated or kneeling. Encourage your dog to place front paws on your chest. Reward calmly.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually increase distance so the dog begins doing small hops toward your arms.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When both of you are comfortable, open your arms and support the dog’s weight as they hop up. Slowly build height, working toward a controlled jump into standing arms.
General Tips: Always keep knees bent and catch low at first. Support your dog’s body fully. Keep sessions short to avoid strain.
Troubleshooting: If the dog is nervous, stay at the paw-on-chest stage longer. If jumping too high, reduce excitement. If your dog twists midair, lower the distance.
Preparation Tips: Use soft flooring and practice low jumps first. Warm up shoulders and core.
Training Insights: This trick relies on physical safety—go extremely slow and stop if your dog shows hesitation.
Achievement Level 3: Full-height jump with stable landing.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs safe controlled jump into arms on cue.

Name: Jump Through the Circle
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Teaches the dog to jump through a hoop or your arms in a circle shape.
Long Description: Jump Through the Circle builds agility skills, body awareness, and confident jumping. It is visually impressive and improves focus and precision.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold your arms or a hoop low and wide. Lure your dog through the opening and reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually raise the circle slightly and reduce reliance on the lure, encouraging your dog to jump through confidently.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue such as 'Through' once consistent, and slowly increase height or distance depending on the dog’s confidence and athleticism.
General Tips: Start with a very low opening. Reward generously. Keep jumps small to protect joints.
Troubleshooting: If the dog tries to go around instead of through, block the sides gently. If they hesitate, make the opening larger. If nervous, practice with the hoop placed on the ground first.
Preparation Tips: Use a hoop or form a human circle with arms. Practice on grass or soft flooring.
Training Insights: Jump-through tricks are excellent for building athletic confidence safely when taught gradually.
Achievement Level 1: Steps or hops through low circle.
Achievement Level 2: Jumps through mid-height circle on cue.
Achievement Level 3: Performs full-height or running jumps in distracting environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog jumps confidently through any circle on cue.

Name: Jump Over the Arm
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Teaches the dog to jump safely over your outstretched arm.
Long Description: Jump Over the Arm is a fun and athletic trick that improves coordination, precision, and confidence. It teaches dogs how to judge height, jump safely, and follow body cues.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Sit or kneel and extend your arm very low to the ground. Use a treat to lure your dog over your arm and reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Slowly raise your arm a few centimetres at a time as your dog becomes confident.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add your verbal cue such as 'Over!' once the behaviour becomes predictable, gradually phasing out the lure.
General Tips: Keep jumps very low at first. Reward enthusiasm. Train on soft surfaces.
Troubleshooting: If your dog goes around, block the sides gently. If hesitant, lower your arm. If they knock your arm, reduce height and rebuild confidence.
Progressions: Circle Jumps, Agility Bars, Trick Routines
Preparation Tips: Train on grass or mats, use medium-value treats, keep your arm stable.
Training Insights: This trick builds confidence in controlled jumping and body awareness.
Achievement Level 3: Performs high or running jumps on cue.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs smooth, confident jumps on cue anywhere.

Name: Play Dead / 'Bang'
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lie on their side and remain still as if 'playing dead.'
Long Description: Play Dead is a theatrical trick that builds impulse control, body awareness, and confidence in holding still. It also strengthens handling comfort because the dog learns to relax on their side.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with your dog in a down position. Lure their head toward their shoulder until they roll onto their side. Mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add the cue 'Bang!' or 'Play Dead' once the behaviour is predictable and begin phasing out the lure.
General Tips: Use soft flooring. Keep sessions calm. Reward calm stillness.
Troubleshooting: If your dog pops up quickly, reduce duration expectations. If they won’t roll fully, reward partial side-lying. If unsure, use very slow lures and reward heavily.
Progressions: Advanced Theatrical Tricks, Calm Handling Behaviours
Preparation Tips: Use a soft mat and quiet space.
Training Insights: This trick helps dogs build trust and comfort with handling and relaxation.
Achievement Level 3: Performs dramatic play-dead in busy settings.
Pass Criteria: Dog rolls onto side and remains still.
Fail Criteria: Dog pops up immediately or resists.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs a long, calm play-dead on cue anywhere.

Name: Down-Stay
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lie down and remain there until released.
Long Description: Down-Stay builds impulse control, reliability, and calmness. It helps dogs learn to hold positions despite distractions, which is essential for real-life manners, safety, and advanced training.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Cue your dog to lie down. Mark and reward instantly.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add distractions such as small movements, stepping away, or placing treats nearby. Eventually proof in new environments.
General Tips: Start with very short durations. Reward frequently. Always release clearly with a release word.
Troubleshooting: If the dog breaks position, reduce duration or distractions. If they keep sitting up, reward more frequently. If distracted, move to a quieter environment.
Preparation Tips: Use a soft mat and small treats. Start in a quiet room.
Training Insights: Down-Stay teaches patience, calmness, and self-control—skills needed throughout life.
Achievement Level 3: Holds down in public for long periods.
Pass Criteria: Dog remains in down until released.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains down-stay through distractions, distance, and duration.

Name: Sit-Stay
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to remain in a sitting position until released.
Long Description: Sit-Stay improves discipline, impulse control, and reliability. It is a fundamental obedience behaviour needed for safe public behaviour, greeting manners, and everyday home routines.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Cue your dog to sit, then reward immediately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add duration by waiting a few seconds before rewarding again. Gradually extend the time.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add distractions such as stepping away, opening a door, or placing toys nearby. Eventually practice in busier environments.
General Tips: Reward frequently at first. Use clear release cues. Keep early sessions short.
Troubleshooting: If the dog breaks position, reduce expectations. If they slide into a down, shorten duration. If distracted, practice indoors first.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and start in a quiet room.
Training Insights: Sit-Stay creates reliable manners and teaches dogs to pause and think before acting.
Achievement Level 3: Holds sit in public for extended periods.
Mastery Criteria: Performs solid sit-stay in all environments and scenarios.

Name: Come Front
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog comes and sits neatly in front of you.
Long Description: Come Front is a precise recall position used in obedience and everyday life. It builds accuracy, focus, and handler engagement.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by calling your dog toward you using an excited tone.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: As they approach, lure them into a straight sit facing you. Mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Front' once they reliably move into position. Gradually fade the lure and increase distance.
General Tips: Reward frequently. Keep your body still. Use straight-line setups.
Troubleshooting: If crooked, use a wall to guide alignment. If stopping short, use higher-value treats. If distracted, shorten distance.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and clear approach path.
Training Insights: Front position teaches precision and strengthens recall.
Achievement Level 3: Performs from distance with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs perfect fronts consistently.

Name: Finish (Left Finish)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog swings into heel position from the front sit.
Long Description: Finish teaches a dog to rotate or swing into perfect heel position. It improves precision and supports advanced obedience.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: With your dog sitting in Front, lure them around your left leg in a half-circle into Heel.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark when they arrive straight at your side.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Finish' as the dog begins the motion. Fade lure over time.
General Tips: Move slowly. Reward when straight. Keep stance steady.
Troubleshooting: If wide, lure closer. If confused, shorten arc. If cutting behind, guide with a treat.
Preparation Tips: Use small treats and practice indoors.
Training Insights: Finish teaches precise hind-end movement and heel alignment.
Achievement Level 3: Performs clean finish in busy places.
Mastery Criteria: Dog swings smoothly into heel.

Name: Side (Right Heel)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog positions on handler’s right side.
Long Description: Side mirrors Heel but on the right, teaching versatility and improving body awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still and lure your dog to your right side.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they sit straight beside you, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Side' and fade the lure with repetition.
General Tips: Reward calm sits. Keep body position clear.
Troubleshooting: If dog sits crooked, practice beside a wall. If lagging, use higher-value treats.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and a quiet space.
Training Insights: Side improves symmetry and handler focus.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains Side in public or during movement.
Mastery Criteria: Dog consistently positions cleanly on cue.

Name: Middle
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog sits or stands between your legs facing forward.
Long Description: Middle boosts confidence, provides a safe position in crowds, and improves rear-end awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still with legs slightly apart and lure your dog between them from the front.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark when they stand or sit centered between your legs.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Middle' and fade the lure over time.
General Tips: Stand relaxed. Reward calmness. Keep space wide.
Troubleshooting: If dog hesitates, widen stance. If they back out, lower lure position. If unsure, work slowly.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and a wide stance.
Training Insights: Middle increases confidence and builds strong handler focus.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains position in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog confidently holds Middle anywhere.

Name: Behind
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog moves behind the handler and lines up directly at the back.
Long Description: Behind teaches rear-position alignment, improves body awareness, and prepares the dog for advanced heelwork transitions and crowd-navigation routines.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still and lure your dog behind your legs using a treat, allowing them to walk around your side and settle directly behind you.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward as soon as they are positioned straight behind your legs.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Behind' once they can complete the movement reliably, then gradually fade the lure.
General Tips: Move slowly. Reward straight alignment. Use clear body guidance.
Troubleshooting: If the dog circles too wide, shorten the arc. If they hesitate, lower the lure. If crooked, practice near a wall to guide straightness.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and practice in an open space.
Training Insights: Behind builds excellent rear-end awareness and helps dogs navigate space confidently.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains position behind in public settings.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably goes behind on cue in any environment.

Name: Go Around
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Dog moves in a circle around an object or the handler.
Long Description: Go Around builds directional confidence, improves focus, and helps dogs understand independent movement away from the handler—a key skill in distance work and agility.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand next to a cone, chair, or your leg and lure your dog around it in a full circle.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually increase the distance from which the dog begins the circle, rewarding each successful rotation.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Around' once they anticipate the motion and begin to complete it without the lure.
General Tips: Choose a large object at first. Keep movements slow. Reward consistent curves.
Troubleshooting: If the dog cuts the arc, use a larger object. If hesitant, shorten the circle. If distracted, work indoors.
Preparation Tips: Use a cone or large object and small treats.
Training Insights: Go Around teaches independence and strong directional control.
Achievement Level 3: Performs at distance with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog circles confidently at distance in any environment.

Name: Back Up
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Dog walks backward on cue.
Long Description: Back Up improves rear-end awareness, balance, and precision. It helps dogs learn spatial boundaries and is useful for tight spaces or formal obedience routines.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand facing your dog and take a slow step forward into their space, encouraging them to take a step backward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward every step your dog takes backward, gradually increasing the number of steps.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Back Up' once they begin offering backward motion reliably.
General Tips: Move slowly. Keep posture tall. Reward each backward step early on.
Troubleshooting: If the dog sits, reduce pressure. If they turn sideways, practice near a wall. If stuck, use a lure near the chest.
Preparation Tips: Practice in hallways or near walls to guide straight lines.
Training Insights: Back Up teaches precision movement and strengthens hind-end coordination.
Achievement Level 3: Backs up straight with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog backs up straight and reliably in all environments.

Name: Forward
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog moves forward on cue in a straight line.
Long Description: Forward teaches controlled movement and is essential for heelwork, rally obedience, agility, and general handler guidance.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with your dog in Heel or at your side. Step forward and mark/reward when your dog moves forward with you.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Reward for staying aligned and maintaining the forward motion.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Forward' once your dog begins to anticipate the movement.
General Tips: Use short steps at first. Reward alignment. Keep your pace consistent.
Troubleshooting: If the dog lags, increase reward rate. If forging, slow down and reset. If drifting, practice near a wall.
Preparation Tips: Use a quiet space and have high-value treats ready.
Training Insights: Forward teaches responsive movement and strengthens handler-dog connection.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains direction in busy environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains a straight, controlled forward motion in any setting.

Name: Easy
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Signals the dog to slow down.
Long Description: Easy teaches dogs to reduce speed, improving leash control and preventing pulling.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin walking and slow your pace deliberately.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward when your dog matches your slower pace.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Easy' as your dog slows, reinforcing calm controlled walking.
General Tips: Use calm tone. Reward often. Keep leash loose.
Troubleshooting: If the dog pulls, stop and reset. If rushing, shorten distance. If distracted, move to quieter area.
