Preparation Tips: Use treats and a quiet area.
Training Insights: 'Easy' helps dogs regulate arousal during walks.
Achievement Level 3: Slows in busy settings.
Mastery Criteria: Dog slows on cue anywhere.

Name: Let's Go
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Signals dog to move forward with handler.
Long Description: Let's Go creates smooth walking transitions and keeps the dog engaged on walks.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Say 'Let's Go' and step forward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward when your dog follows with a loose leash.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Repeat often to build automatic engagement.
General Tips: Use upbeat voice. Keep leash slack. Reward engagement.
Troubleshooting: If pulling, reset. If lagging, motivate with treats. If distracted, shorten duration.
Preparation Tips: Prepare treats and start indoors.
Training Insights: Let's Go becomes a default walking transition cue.
Achievement Level 3: Follows on cue in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog responds instantly in all settings.

Name: With Me
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Dog walks close beside handler while staying attentive.
Long Description: With Me teaches focused walking without demanding perfect heel position.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold treats near your leg and step forward, marking when your dog stays close.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Reward consistently for staying in the “zone” near your leg.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'With Me' as your dog maintains proximity.
General Tips: Keep movements slow. Use frequent rewards. Practice indoors first.
Troubleshooting: If drifting, shorten distance. If distracted, increase reward rate. If lagging, use excited voice.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and begin in quiet areas.
Training Insights: With Me builds walking focus without strict obedience rules.
Achievement Level 3: Walks attentively in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains proximity in any environment.

Name: Quiet
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Teaches dog to stop barking on cue.
Long Description: Quiet helps dogs manage arousal and reduces nuisance barking by teaching calm behaviour on command.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Allow your dog to bark briefly, then wait for a moment of silence.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward the instant your dog stops barking.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Quiet' just before they naturally pause, reinforcing calmness.
General Tips: Reward calm behaviour. Stay patient. Avoid yelling.
Troubleshooting: If dog barks continuously, remove triggers. If too excited, increase distance. If confused, reward very short quiet moments.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and start in low-distraction setting.
Training Insights: Quiet builds emotional control and supports polite manners.
Achievement Level 3: Remains quiet in stimulating environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog stops barking on cue anywhere.

Name: Go Potty
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Teaches the dog to toilet on cue.
Long Description: Go Potty provides structure for house training, travel, and predictable bathroom routines.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Take your dog to a consistent toileting area.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they begin to eliminate, softly say your cue (e.g., 'Go Potty') and reward when finished.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Repeat daily until the dog reliably toilets shortly after arriving in the spot.
General Tips: Keep tone calm. Use same location. Reward immediately after they finish.
Troubleshooting: If distracted, wait quietly. If unsure, decrease space. If sniffing aimlessly, walk in small circles.
Preparation Tips: Use leash and treats; choose a consistent toilet zone.
Training Insights: Go Potty builds reliable toileting habits and reduces accidents.
Achievement Level 3: Toilets on cue in new environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog toilets promptly on cue anywhere.

Name: Kennel
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches dog to enter crate willingly.
Long Description: Kennel creates a safe resting routine and supports house training, travel, and independence.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Keep crate open and place treats or toys near the entrance.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Lure your dog into the crate, marking and rewarding as they step inside.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Kennel' once they enter confidently and begin to offer the behaviour.
General Tips: Keep crate positive. Never force. Use calm rewards.
Troubleshooting: If hesitant, start with front paws only. If fearful, open all sides if possible. If whining, wait for quiet before opening door.
Preparation Tips: Use comfy bedding, treats, and quiet training space.
Training Insights: Kennel builds confidence and comfort with confinement.
Achievement Level 3: Enters in any environment or during distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog enters crate eagerly on cue.

Name: Load Up
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Dog jumps into car or onto a surface on cue.
Long Description: Load Up is a functional skill for travel, grooming tables, and getting onto elevated surfaces safely.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand near the car or platform and pat the surface with a treat lure.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When the dog steps or jumps up, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Load Up' once they show confidence, and gradually remove the lure.
General Tips: Start with low surfaces. Reward calm landings. Keep footing secure.
Troubleshooting: If hesitant, lower the surface. If dog slips, change footing. If anxious, break into smaller steps.
Preparation Tips: Use stable surfaces and tasty treats.
Training Insights: Load Up improves confidence in navigating new surfaces and environments.
Achievement Level 3: Loads reliably in busy areas.
Mastery Criteria: Dog loads confidently on cue anywhere.

Name: Out
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Tells dog to leave a room, crate, or area.
Long Description: Out is important for boundaries, safety, and resource-guarding prevention.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand near doorway or boundary and step toward the opening while luring the dog forward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward when they cross the threshold.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Out' once they understand moving out of the space is the goal.
General Tips: Use calm movement. Reward outside the boundary. Keep directions clear.
Troubleshooting: If dog resists, widen doorway. If they re-enter quickly, block gently. If confused, use clearer lures.
Preparation Tips: Choose a clear boundary line or doorway.
Training Insights: Out teaches polite boundaries without confrontation.
Achievement Level 3: Leaves area calmly under distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog leaves any space on cue, calmly and reliably.

Name: Bring It Here
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Dog retrieves an item and returns it to handler.
Long Description: Bring It Here strengthens recall, cooperation, and functional retrieving skills.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by giving your dog a toy and encouraging them to hold it.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Step backward excitedly to encourage the dog to return to you. Mark and reward when they bring the item.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Bring it here' once your dog reliably returns the item.
General Tips: Use excited tone. Reward returning movement. Keep items easy to carry.
Troubleshooting: If dog runs away, use long line. If dropping early, reward earlier. If disinterested, use higher-value toy.
Preparation Tips: Use safe toys and practice in small space.
Training Insights: Bring It Here teaches cooperative play and reliable returns.
Achievement Level 3: Retrieves in busy environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog retrieves promptly on cue anywhere.

Name: Give
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog releases item to handler.
Long Description: Give teaches safe item release and prevents guarding behaviors.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a treat near your dog’s nose while they hold a toy.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: When they release the toy to take the treat, mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Give' once release becomes predictable.
General Tips: Use calm tone. Always offer fair trades. Avoid pulling object away.
Troubleshooting: If dog holds tighter, use higher-value treat. If runs away, practice on leash. If reluctant, start with low-value items.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and easy items.
Training Insights: Give teaches trust and cooperation around objects.
Achievement Level 3: Releases high-value items calmly.
Mastery Criteria: Dog gives any item calmly on cue.

Name: Settle
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog relaxes in place on cue.
Long Description: Settle teaches calmness, emotional regulation, and polite resting behavior.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Guide your dog to a mat or bed and reward any calm behaviors (lying down, sighing, relaxed posture).
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually reinforce longer periods of stillness.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Settle' once your dog naturally relaxes on the mat.
General Tips: Keep tone soft. Reward calmness, not excitement. Use consistent location early on.
Troubleshooting: If restless, shorten duration. If leaving mat, guide back gently. If overstimulated, reduce environment excitement.
Preparation Tips: Use mat and soft treats.
Training Insights: Settle builds lifelong calmness and self-regulation skills.
Achievement Level 3: Settles anywhere for extended periods.
Mastery Criteria: Dog settles calmly in any environment.

Name: Enough / All Done
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Signals that activity or behavior should stop.
Long Description: Enough teaches dogs when play, barking, or attention-seeking is finished.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stop play or engagement and stand still.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Say 'Enough' or 'All Done' calmly as you disengage.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reward your dog once they shift into calm behavior, reinforcing the meaning of the cue.
General Tips: Stay consistent. Use calm voice. Never punish.
Troubleshooting: If dog persists, ignore briefly. If overly excited, redirect to mat. If confused, practice ending sessions often.
Preparation Tips: Use neutral body language.
Training Insights: Enough teaches boundaries and smooth transitions out of activity.
Achievement Level 3: Disengages from high excitement on cue.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably stops and calms on cue in all situations.

Name: Go Say Hi
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Dog approaches a person or dog calmly when given permission.
Long Description: Go Say Hi teaches polite greetings, impulse control, and safe social interactions.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with your dog in a Sit or Wait. Approach the person slowly.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Say 'Go Say Hi' and allow your dog to walk forward to greet calmly while you supervise.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reward your dog for calm sniffing and checking in with you.
General Tips: Keep greetings short. Reward calmness. Never allow pulling toward people.
Troubleshooting: If dog jumps, end greeting. If nervous, increase distance. If too excited, slow approach.
Preparation Tips: Choose calm greeters and use leash control.
Training Insights: Go Say Hi creates reliable permission-based social behavior.
Achievement Level 3: Greets politely in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog greets politely and returns on cue.

Name: Wait for Food
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog waits calmly before being released to eat.
Long Description: Wait for Food builds impulse control and household manners.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold your dog’s food bowl and wait for calm stillness.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Lower the bowl slowly; raise it again if your dog moves.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When calmness is consistent, add the cue 'Wait' and release with your release word.
General Tips: Move slowly. Use soft voice. Release consistently.
Troubleshooting: If dog lunges, raise bowl. If restless, shorten duration. If confused, start with empty bowl.
Preparation Tips: Use quiet feeding area and stable bowl.
Training Insights: This routine builds strong impulse control for daily life.
Achievement Level 3: Waits through distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably waits for food anywhere.

Name: Take a Break
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Signals end of focused training or engagement.
Long Description: Take a Break teaches dogs to relax after structured work.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stop interacting and step back from your dog.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Say 'Take a Break' and disengage.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reward your dog for calm independent behavior.
General Tips: Keep tone neutral. Use consistently at session end.
Troubleshooting: If dog follows persistently, ignore briefly. If overstimulated, redirect to mat. If confused, shorten sessions.
Preparation Tips: Use calm body language.
Training Insights: Take a Break supports work–rest balance and emotional regulation.
Achievement Level 3: Transitions to calmness anywhere.
Mastery Criteria: Dog transitions smoothly on cue in any environment.

Name: Move
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Tells dog to step out of the handler’s path.
Long Description: Move encourages safe repositioning and reduces crowding or blocking.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Step gently toward your dog’s space.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward as soon as they step aside.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Move' once they reliably shift out of your way.
General Tips: Use gentle body pressure. Reward instantly. Keep motion slow.
Troubleshooting: If dog freezes, reduce pressure. If confused, use a lure. If resistant, reward tiny shifts.
Preparation Tips: Train indoors with predictable setup.
Training Insights: Move improves spatial awareness and cooperation.
Achievement Level 3: Moves on cue in busy situations.
Mastery Criteria: Dog moves immediately with minimal handler motion.

Name: Wait at Doors
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog pauses and waits at a door until released.
Long Description: Wait at Doors teaches safety, prevents dashing, and builds impulse control and respect for boundaries.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Walk your dog to a closed door on leash. Ask for a Sit or Stand and say 'Wait.'
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Slowly open the door a few centimetres. If your dog stays still, mark and reward. If they move, gently close the door and reset.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually open further and release with a cue when your dog remains steady.
General Tips: Move slowly. Reward calmness. Use consistent release cue.
Troubleshooting: If dog rushes forward, close door calmly. If restless, shorten duration. If confused, practice with interior doors first.
Preparation Tips: Use a low-distraction door and small treats.
Training Insights: This cue reinforces safety and polite household movement.
Achievement Level 3: Waits fully with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably waits at any doorway in all environments.

Name: Cross
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog crosses legs on cue (or crosses behind handler, depending on chosen definition).
Long Description: Cross is commonly used as a trick where the dog crosses one paw over the other, or as a directional cue for crossing behind the handler. Here it is defined as a paw-crossing trick that builds body awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Ask your dog for a Sit or Down. Gently lure one front paw across the other paw using a treat.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward any crossing movement, even small ones. Shape until the paw fully overlaps the other.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Cross' once they consistently offer the movement.
General Tips: Reward tiny steps. Keep sessions short. Work on soft surfaces.
Troubleshooting: If the dog lifts wrong paw, switch lure hand. If confused, break into micro-movements. If stiff, warm up with paw tricks.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and practice on a comfortable mat.
Training Insights: Cross increases fine motor control and is visually impressive.
Achievement Level 3: Holds crossed paws for photos or in public.
Fail Criteria: Dog lifts wrong paw or avoids.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs a clear, steady cross on cue anywhere.

Name: Wave / Wave Goodbye
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Teaches the dog to lift a paw and wave on cue.
Long Description: Wave is a cute, crowd-pleasing behaviour where the dog lifts one paw in a waving motion. It builds paw awareness and is often used in performance routines.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Ask your dog for a paw or high five. Before they make contact, pull your hand back slightly so they lift their paw higher.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward the upward movement. Gradually shape for a repeated 'wave' motion.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Wave' or 'Say Goodbye' when the behaviour is consistent and fade the lure.
General Tips: Reward small lifts. Keep sessions short. Use soft surfaces.
Troubleshooting: If dog hits your hand, pull hand away sooner. If unsure, start by shaping any paw lift. If switching paws, block one side gently.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and sit your dog comfortably.
Training Insights: Wave improves coordination and is a low-effort, high-impact trick.
Achievement Level 3: Waves in public or with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog waves multiple times on cue anywhere.

Name: Speak
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Teaches the dog to bark on cue.
Long Description: Speak allows controlled barking and helps dogs learn communication on command.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Trigger a natural bark using excitement or knocking, then mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add the cue 'Speak' just before they bark.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Reinforce calmness and only a single bark at a time.
General Tips: Keep calm tone. Reward only one bark. Pair with Quiet.
Troubleshooting: If dog barks nonstop, stop rewarding. If scared, use gentle triggers. If confused, reward any vocalization.
Preparation Tips: Use consistent triggers and small treats.
Training Insights: Speak builds communication control and improves arousal management.
Achievement Level 3: Performs controlled bark anywhere.
Mastery Criteria: Dog offers single bark on cue in all environments.

Name: Figure 8
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog weaves in a figure-eight pattern around your legs.
Long Description: Figure 8 builds coordination, confidence, and engagement. It is a flowing, attractive trick for performances.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand with legs apart. Lure your dog around your right leg.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Then lure them around your left, marking each pass.
General Tips: Keep stance wide. Move slowly. Reward each loop.
Troubleshooting: If dog circles too wide, lure closer. If confused, practice one loop at a time. If distracted, work indoors.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and open space.
Training Insights: Figure 8 builds smooth body movement and handler focus.
Achievement Level 3: Continuous fluid figure 8s in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs smooth fast figure 8s on cue anywhere.

Name: Legs (Walk Between Legs)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog walks forward between the handler’s legs.
Long Description: Legs improves confidence, handler connection, and body awareness. It looks impressive in routines and is great for shy dogs.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still with legs apart and lure your dog between them.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take one step at a time, rewarding the dog for staying between your legs.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Legs' once the dog walks confidently in position.
General Tips: Keep stance wide. Reward frequently. Move slowly.
Troubleshooting: If dog backs out, lower lure. If nervous, widen stance. If distracted, shorten sessions.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and a wide stance.
Training Insights: Legs boosts confidence and body awareness.
Achievement Level 3: Walks long distances or in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains position smoothly on cue anywhere.

Name: Orbit
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog circles around the handler in a smooth loop.
Long Description: Orbit is a flowing, flashy trick where the dog moves around the handler’s body. It builds confidence, coordination, and rear-end awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a treat near your dog’s nose and lure them behind you in a half‑circle.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Continue the lure until they complete a full circle around your body.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Orbit' once your dog consistently follows the circular path, then fade the lure.
General Tips: Move slowly. Reward full circles. Keep your stance steady.
Troubleshooting: If the dog cuts the circle, lure closer. If they drift away, shorten distance. If confused, practice half‑circles first.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and an open space.
Training Insights: Orbit develops fluid movement and great handler awareness.
Achievement Level 3: Performs fast orbit in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs tight orbit on cue anywhere.

Name: Moonwalk
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog walks backward between the handler’s legs.
Long Description: Moonwalk is an impressive reverse movement trick that requires coordination, confidence, and hind‑end awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin with your dog standing in the Legs position.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take a very small step backward, rewarding your dog for moving backward with you.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Moonwalk' once the dog begins backing up smoothly between your legs.
General Tips: Move slowly. Reward every backward step. Keep posture stable.
Troubleshooting: If dog steps out, reduce distance. If confused, practice Back Up separately. If nervous, widen stance.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and soft flooring.
Training Insights: Moonwalk builds advanced hind‑end control and confidence.
Achievement Level 3: Performs long moonwalk in public.
Mastery Criteria: Smooth backward movement on cue anywhere.

Name: Balance Treat
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog balances a treat on nose or paw until released.
Long Description: Balance Treat builds patience, impulse control, and flashy performance skill.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Ask your dog for a Sit or Down and reward calm stillness.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gently place a treat on their nose or paw while supporting their chin if needed.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add a release cue like 'Okay!' and reward when they hold the treat until released.
General Tips: Use soft treats. Keep sessions short. Reward calmness.
Troubleshooting: If dog drops treat early, shorten duration. If too excited, use lower‑value treats. If stressed, switch to paw version first.
Preparation Tips: Use low‑value treats and calm environment.
Training Insights: Balance Treat strengthens patience and precision.
Achievement Level 3: Balances treat with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds treat calmly on cue anywhere.

Name: Catch
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog catches treats or toys in the air.
Long Description: Catch improves coordination, timing, and engagement.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start by tossing a treat very gently toward your dog's mouth from a short distance.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward any attempt to grab it mid‑air.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually increase distance and height as your dog improves.
General Tips: Use small soft treats. Toss gently. Keep dog facing you.
Troubleshooting: If dog misses often, toss slower. If too excited, pause between reps. If chasing fallen treats, toss upward not forward.
Preparation Tips: Use soft treats and start indoors.
Training Insights: Catch builds accuracy and strengthens engagement with handler.
Achievement Level 3: Catches at distance or fast tosses.
Mastery Criteria: Dog catches reliably from any reasonable distance.

Name: Peekaboo
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog steps behind handler and peeks head between legs.
Long Description: Peekaboo is a cute, confidence‑boosting trick where the dog positions behind you and pokes their head through your legs. It’s great for shy dogs and creates a fun performance pose.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still and lure your dog behind you.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Bring the treat between your legs so your dog pokes their head through from behind. Mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Peekaboo' as they move into position, then fade the lure.
General Tips: Keep stance wide. Reward calmness. Move slowly.
Troubleshooting: If dog circles around, shorten lure path. If hesitant, widen stance. If confused, practice from a sit first.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and open space.
Training Insights: Peekaboo builds confidence and handler engagement.
Achievement Level 3: Holds position in public.
Mastery Criteria: Dog pops into Peekaboo on cue anywhere.

Name: Skateboard
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 20, Level 3 by Week 24
Short Description: Dog stands on and pushes a skateboard.
Long Description: Skateboard is an eye‑catching trick that teaches balance, body control, and confidence on moving surfaces.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Place the skateboard on a non‑moving surface (grass or carpet) and reward your dog for investigating.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Shape front‑paws‑on behaviour, marking each time they place feet on the board.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Once confident, move to smooth ground and reinforce gentle pushing motions with back legs.
General Tips: Use non‑moving surface first. Reward investigation. Keep sessions short.
Troubleshooting: If dog is scared of movement, revert to grass. If slipping, use grip tape. If confused, break steps into micro‑shaping.
Preparation Tips: Use a skateboard with good grip and start on carpet.
Training Insights: Skateboard builds advanced balance and confidence.
Achievement Level 3: Rides board confidently on smooth ground.
Mastery Criteria: Dog confidently rides/pushes skateboard on command.

Name: Roll in Blanket
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Dog wraps themselves in a blanket by rolling.
Long Description: Roll in Blanket is a charming trick where the dog rolls into a blanket, creating a cozy ‘tuck‑in’ effect. It uses shaping and confidence around body handling.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Lay out a blanket and encourage your dog to lie down at one end.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Place a treat and lure your dog to roll sideways while the blanket folds over them. Mark any rolling motion.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue ‘Blanket’ when they begin rolling reliably, gradually reducing the lure.
General Tips: Use soft blanket. Reward small rolls. Keep motion slow.
Troubleshooting: If dog resists rolling, return to Play Dead practice. If blanket bunches, smooth it out. If hesitant, reward tiny shifts.
Preparation Tips: Use soft blanket and quiet space.
Training Insights: Roll in Blanket builds body comfort and is adorable in routines.
Achievement Level 3: Full roll‑in on cue.
Mastery Criteria: Dog fully wraps themselves in blanket on cue.

Name: Say Prayers
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Dog places paws on object and bows head as if praying.
Long Description: Say Prayers is a sweet, photogenic trick that teaches balance, precision, and controlled posture.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Have your dog sit and place front paws on a stable object (chair, bed, stool). Mark and reward.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Lure their head downward between their paws, marking slight dips at first.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue ‘Pray’ once they reliably lower their head, then build duration.
General Tips: Use stable object. Reward small head dips. Keep sessions calm.
Troubleshooting: If dog lifts paws, lower object height. If nervous, use softer surfaces. If confused, separate steps further.
Preparation Tips: Use stable prop and treats.
Training Insights: Say Prayers builds balance, focus, and adorable posing behavior.
Achievement Level 3: Performs with distractions for photos/videos.
Fail Criteria: Dog removes paws or resists bowing.
Mastery Criteria: Dog performs full prayer position on cue anywhere.

Name: Back Stall
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 16, Level 2 by Week 20, Level 3 by Week 24
Short Description: Dog jumps onto the handler’s back and balances.
Long Description: Back Stall is a flashy stunt trick where the dog gently hops onto the handler’s back and balances in place. It requires trust, confidence, and excellent body awareness.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by teaching your dog to place front paws on your back while you kneel.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually shape full-body weight onto your back using a low, stable platform behind you.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: When the dog is confident, lower your body and cue them to hop up gently. Reward for balancing.
General Tips: Work on soft ground. Keep sessions short. Ensure dog is confident.
Troubleshooting: If dog is nervous, raise platform height. If sliding, use non-slip clothing. If jumping too hard, lower excitement.
Preparation Tips: Use a mat and supportive clothing.
Training Insights: Back Stall builds trust and advanced balance.
Achievement Level 3: Stall in public or during routines.
Mastery Criteria: Smooth, controlled back stall on cue anywhere.

Name: Footsies
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog places paws on handler’s feet and stays there.
Long Description: Footsies is a sweet bonding trick where the dog gently stands with their front paws on your feet. It's used in dance routines and improves balance.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand still and lure your dog to place both front paws on your feet.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward as soon as they make contact.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Footsies' and gradually increase duration as your dog becomes comfortable.
General Tips: Reward small attempts. Stand still. Keep voice calm.
Troubleshooting: If dog steps off, reduce duration. If nervous, lower body posture. If unbalanced, use flat shoes.
Preparation Tips: Wear stable shoes and stand still.
Training Insights: Footsies encourages trust and body control.
Achievement Level 3: Maintains Footsies while handler moves slightly.
Mastery Criteria: Dog holds Footsies confidently anywhere.

Name: Army Crawl
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog crawls forward while staying low to the ground.
Long Description: Army Crawl is a fun trick that strengthens core muscles and teaches controlled movement.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Place your dog in a Down. Hold a treat close to their nose and lure forward slowly.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Mark and reward any forward crawling movement while keeping elbows down.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Crawl' once the behaviour is consistent, gradually increasing distance.
General Tips: Keep lure low. Reward small movements. Practice on soft ground.
Troubleshooting: If dog stands up, lower lure more. If hesitant, shorten sessions. If sliding, use carpet.
Preparation Tips: Use soft blanket or carpet.
Training Insights: Army Crawl improves strength and body awareness.
Achievement Level 3: Crawls long distance or in public.
Mastery Criteria: Smooth, low crawl on cue anywhere.

Name: Yoga Stretch
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog performs a deep stretching pose (like play bow or forward stretch).
Long Description: Yoga Stretch is a calming trick that encourages natural stretching and can be used for warm-ups before training.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Watch for natural stretching moments (after naps or before walks) and mark the behavior.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add the cue 'Stretch' just as they begin the movement.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Shape longer stretches over time while maintaining a calm environment.
General Tips: Reward naturally. Use calm tone. Capture often.
Troubleshooting: If dog won’t stretch, gently lure into bow. If stiff, warm up with easy movement. If confused, reward partial stretches.
Preparation Tips: Use quiet area and soft ground.
Training Insights: Yoga Stretch encourages calmness and flexibility.
Achievement Level 3: Stretches on cue in busy environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog stretches deeply and reliably on cue anywhere.

Name: Sit on Feet
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog sits between or on the handler’s feet.
Long Description: Sit on Feet is a cozy bonding trick in which the dog sits snugly between or lightly on your feet. It helps build confidence and connection, especially for shy or clingy dogs.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Stand with feet slightly apart. Lure your dog to move between your feet.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Once positioned, gently cue a Sit and reward when they sit between or touching your feet.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Sit on Feet' when the dog reliably moves into the position, increasing duration gradually.
General Tips: Stand still. Reward calmness. Keep stance wide.
Troubleshooting: If dog backs out, lower lure. If unsure, widen stance. If nervous, reward micro‑steps into position.
Preparation Tips: Use treats and stand with steady posture.
Training Insights: Sit on Feet builds closeness and can be used as a grounding position.
Achievement Level 3: Performs in busy environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog calmly holds position on cue anywhere.

Name: Open Door
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 16, Level 2 by Week 20, Level 3 by Week 24
Short Description: Dog opens a door using a tug rope or handle.
Long Description: Open Door teaches functional independence skills by having the dog pull a tug rope or push a lever to open a door.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Attach a tug rope to a door handle and reward your dog for interacting with it.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Shape pulling behaviour by marking any backward tug that moves the door.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Open' when your dog reliably pulls the door open, gradually increasing distance and reducing lure.
General Tips: Use lightweight door. Reward small tugs. Keep door safe.
Troubleshooting: If dog bites rope, switch texture. If hesitant, lower door resistance. If confused, shape tiny tugs.
Preparation Tips: Use tug rope and soft treats.
Training Insights: Open Door builds independence and problem-solving.
Achievement Level 3: Opens different doors in new places.
Mastery Criteria: Opens doors reliably on cue anywhere.

Name: Close Door
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 14, Level 2 by Week 18, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog pushes door shut with nose or paws.
Long Description: Close Door teaches the dog to gently push a door closed, useful for functional household tasks.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a target (sticky note) on the door and encourage your dog to nose‑touch it.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually move the target toward the edge so touches push the door.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Close' once your dog pushes the door fully shut.
General Tips: Use soft-close doors. Mark gentle touches. Reward effort.
Troubleshooting: If dog hits too hard, lower excitement. If scared of noise, soften door. If confused, start with target work.
Preparation Tips: Use sticky notes or targets.
Training Insights: Close Door increases confidence around moving objects.
Achievement Level 3: Closes fully on cue anywhere.
Mastery Criteria: Closes door gently and reliably on cue.

Name: Turn Lights On/Off
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 18, Level 2 by Week 22, Level 3 by Week 26
Short Description: Dog uses nose or paw to activate a light switch.
Long Description: Turning lights on/off is a high-skill task demonstrating targeting precision and confidence with moving switches.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Place a target sticker on the light switch and teach nose or paw targeting.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually fade the target while shaping enough pressure to move the switch.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Lights' when your dog reliably flips the switch.
General Tips: Use large switches. Keep sessions short. Reward small wins.
Troubleshooting: If dog scratches wall, use paw pad target. If afraid of click noise, desensitize slowly. If too gentle, build pressure.
Preparation Tips: Use large-switch practice plate.
Training Insights: This task improves precision and builds advanced task reliability.
Achievement Level 3: Performs task on various switches.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably toggles lights anywhere.

Name: Push Button
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 18
Short Description: Dog presses a button with nose or paw.
Long Description: Push Button teaches dogs to activate devices like automatic doors or communication buttons.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Present a large button and reward any nose or paw touches.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Shape stronger touches until the button activates.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Push' when the dog presses reliably.
General Tips: Use large button. Mark strong touches. Keep button stable.
Troubleshooting: If dog pecks lightly, increase reward for strong touches. If scared of sound, lower volume. If unsure, return to target training.
Preparation Tips: Use stable surface and big button.
Training Insights: Push Button teaches precision and independence tasks.
Achievement Level 3: Presses various buttons confidently.
Mastery Criteria: Dog presses any accessible button on cue.

Name: Ring Bell
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 8, Level 2 by Week 10, Level 3 by Week 12
Short Description: Dog rings a bell with nose or paw to signal a need (e.g., go outside).
Long Description: Ring Bell teaches clear communication and builds independence, often used for potty cues or door alerts.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold or mount a bell at nose height and reward any touch.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Shape stronger touches until the bell makes sound.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue 'Bell' or 'Ring' once your dog reliably activates it.
General Tips: Mount bell securely. Reward clear touches. Keep excitement low.
Troubleshooting: If dog avoids bell, lower height. If too gentle, increase reinforcement. If pawing excessively, switch to nose targeting.
Preparation Tips: Use mounted bell and treats.
Training Insights: Ring Bell improves communication clarity and independence.
Achievement Level 3: Rings bell reliably for communication.
Mastery Criteria: Dog rings bell purposefully on cue or context anywhere.

Name: Tidy Up
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 16, Level 2 by Week 20, Level 3 by Week 24
Short Description: Dog picks up toys and places them into a basket.
Long Description: Tidy Up teaches multi-step task sequencing, building retrieve reliability and organization skills.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start by teaching your dog to pick up a toy and return to you.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Place a basket near you and reward any movement toward it while holding a toy.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Shape dropping the toy into the basket and add the cue 'Tidy Up' once consistent.
General Tips: Use light toys. Keep basket stable. Reward attempts.
Troubleshooting: If dog drops toy early, shorten distance. If confused, start with larger basket. If reluctant, raise reward value.
Preparation Tips: Use toys and stable basket.
Training Insights: Tidy Up builds sequencing, confidence, and purposeful task skills.
Achievement Level 3: Repeats with multiple toys reliably.
Mastery Criteria: Dog tidies multiple toys on cue anywhere.

Name: Find It (Search)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 12, Level 3 by Week 14
Short Description: Dog searches for hidden treats or objects using scent.
Long Description: Find It builds natural scenting ability, confidence, and problem-solving.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Hold a treat or toy in front of your dog, say 'Find it!', and toss it a short distance.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Progress to hiding it in easy places while letting your dog watch.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Hide items without your dog watching and reward any successful search.
General Tips: Start easy. Keep hides simple. Reward generously.
Troubleshooting: If dog gives up, reduce difficulty. If distracted, use higher-value item. If rushing, slow pacing.
Preparation Tips: Use treat or toy and simple hiding spots.
Training Insights: Find It promotes mental stimulation and scent skills.
Achievement Level 3: Searches complex areas reliably.
Mastery Criteria: Dog searches independently and thoroughly on cue anywhere.

Name: Find (Object Name)
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 20, Level 2 by Week 24, Level 3 by Week 28
Short Description: Dog retrieves a specific item by name.
Long Description: Find (Object Name) teaches advanced discrimination and complex retrieval behaviour used in service and assistance work.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Start with one object (e.g., 'Keys'). Encourage your dog to touch or retrieve it while repeating the name and rewarding heavily.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Add a second object with a different name and reward correct selection.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Increase the number of items and distance, reinforcing accurate discrimination and retrieval.
General Tips: Start with distinct objects. Use clear names. Reward correct choices strongly.
Troubleshooting: If dog guesses, reduce choices. If confused, return to single-item reps. If hesitant, refresh basics.
Preparation Tips: Use 2–3 distinct objects.
Training Insights: Object discrimination builds advanced cognitive and retrieval skills.
Achievement Level 3: Retrieves named items from distance or other rooms.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably retrieves named items from anywhere.

Name: Track
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 20, Level 2 by Week 26, Level 3 by Week 30
Short Description: Dog follows a scent trail on the ground.
Long Description: Tracking builds advanced scenting ability, focus, and working drive. It teaches the dog to follow a specific scent path to locate a person or object.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by dragging a treat or scent article along the ground in a straight line, placing small rewards along the track.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Bring your dog to the start, say ‘Track’, and allow them to follow the scent trail to the end.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Gradually increase length, turns, and complexity, reducing food rewards over time.
General Tips: Start with simple trails. Use calm tone. Reward often.
Troubleshooting: If dog wanders, shorten track. If overwhelmed, lay fresher scent. If distracted, use higher-value rewards.
Preparation Tips: Use scent article and long line.
Training Insights: Tracking teaches discipline, scent focus, and confidence outdoors.
Achievement Level 3: Tracks long, complex trails with distractions.
Mastery Criteria: Dog reliably tracks long trails in varied environments.

Name: Scent Discrimination
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 22, Level 2 by Week 28, Level 3 by Week 32
Short Description: Dog identifies and indicates a matching scent among multiple choices.
Long Description: Scent Discrimination builds cognitive precision and advanced olfactory skill, central to scentwork, obedience, and assistance tasks.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Present your dog with a scented item (e.g., your glove) and reward them for investigating.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Place the scented item among identical unscented objects and reward correct indications.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Increase number of decoys, distance, and complexity, adding a clear indication behaviour such as a sit or nose freeze.
General Tips: Use identical objects. Reward heavily. Keep sessions short.
Troubleshooting: If dog guesses, reduce options. If overwhelmed, simplify. If hesitant, refresh scent association.
Preparation Tips: Use clean identical items and gloves.
Training Insights: Scent Discrimination enhances precision and mental challenge.
Achievement Level 2: Finds correct scent in moderate setups.
Achievement Level 3: Performs reliable discrimination in varied environments.
Mastery Criteria: Dog discriminates scent accurately anywhere.

Name: Carry
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 12, Level 2 by Week 16, Level 3 by Week 20
Short Description: Dog carries an item while walking.
Long Description: Carry teaches reliable retrieval and calm transport of items over distance, useful for assistance tasks and working dog foundations.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Begin by teaching your dog to hold an item in their mouth while sitting.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Take a step forward and reward if they keep holding the item.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue ‘Carry’ once your dog can walk several steps without dropping.
General Tips: Start with light object. Reward frequently. Keep duration short.
Troubleshooting: If dog drops item, shorten distance. If chewing, switch item. If distracted, practice indoors first.
Preparation Tips: Use lightweight item.
Training Insights: Carry builds confidence and calm working behaviour.
Achievement Level 3: Carries reliably outdoors or to person.
Mastery Criteria: Carries item calmly on cue anywhere.

Name: Hold
Ideal Stage: Level 1 by Week 10, Level 2 by Week 14, Level 3 by Week 16
Short Description: Dog holds an object calmly without chewing or dropping.
Long Description: Hold builds the foundation for all advanced retrieve tasks, from service dog work to competition obedience.
Detailed Instructions Step 1: Present the object (dumbbell, toy, or handle) and reward your dog for taking it gently.
Detailed Instructions Step 2: Gradually build duration by rewarding longer holds with a calm, closed mouth.
Detailed Instructions Step 3: Add the cue ‘Hold’ when your dog reliably takes and maintains grip.
General Tips: Reward calm mouth. Use neutral tone. Avoid tugging.
Troubleshooting: If dog chews, reset quickly. If drops, shorten duration. If avoids item, switch texture.
Preparation Tips: Use smooth object and calm space.
Training Insights: Hold builds impulse control, grip strength, and retrieve reliability.
Achievement Level 3: Holds reliably with distractions or during movement.
Mastery Criteria: Dog maintains calm grip anywhere on cue.
